content.webTitle: She's the voice: how the governor-general's wife became Australia's singing sovereign

fields.headline: She's the voice: how the governor-general's wife became Australia's singing sovereign
fields.bodyText: Her excellency Linda Hurley has a song for every occasion: the Legacy widows morning tea, an employee off to get married, and the Canberra Hospital Foundation dinner all got special compositions. But mostly Hurley, a former teacher and the wife of the governor general, David Hurley, has one song for everyone: You Are My Sunshine. Since the Hurleys moved from New South Wales Government House in May back to Canberra, the song has become a staple that she deploys to boost morale of staff and guests at official functions. “But just the chorus, the verses are sad,” she says. I’ve spent the morning watching Hurley wander between tables of war widows (average age 81, according to the governor general), microphone in hand, leading them in song over cucumber and smoked salmon sandwiches. Every song is an all-in special and not knowing the words is no excuse – guests are provided a Government House song book so they don’t stumble as they are led through a repertoire that includes It’s a Long Way to Tipperary, When the Red, Red Robin and Singin’ in the Rain. “My biggest passion is to get people to sing,” Hurley tells Guardian Australia. “Australia, I believe, has had it beaten out of them – if you weren’t perfect, if you didn’t get picked in the choir, that person goes away for the rest of their life believing they can’t sing. “I can’t say how many men have told me that they can’t sing. And it’s because they were told when they were six they wouldn’t be in the choir … Or kids are told to mime, just move your lips. “We wouldn’t say that if a child can’t read well – we wouldn’t say ‘You’re really not good at reading, just give it a miss’, or maths or any other subject.” The curious practice developed 18 months into David Hurley’s term as NSW governor, first with Linda adding her own lyrics to the tune of I am Australian for a ball to celebrate 170 years of Government House. It then developed into full-blown compositions with the help of “a navy band man” and David Butts. Butts, the musician dressed in blue from Wiggles forerunner the Hooley Dooleys, came on as a speechwriter but then helped Hurley realise her dream to write and stage a musical at Government House. “I wasn’t allowed to coerce anyone to be in it, so it was put out to the staff: ‘If you want to be in the Government House musical’ … They all – a lot of them – rallied. I taught each group their song, then it was up to them how to perform it, they had props, they could do whatever they liked. “At the end the staff said ‘Why didn’t we do this three years ago?’ They felt it was … a real bonding thing.” Staff are not universally pleased with the practice but Hurley insists it is for everyone’s own good. She cites studies that show singing has health benefits but most of all she relies on the testimony of her own guests. “The women today said, ‘Oh that made us all feel happier’.” “No one has come up to me and said ‘I’m never coming here again, that’s the most ridiculous thing I’ve seen at Government House’. “They probably wouldn’t say that to me, they’d be well mannered enough not to.” But there are limits. “Sometimes I get a little bit nervous, how it might go. If the Queen came here, for example, I wouldn’t sing at a reception with the Queen. I wouldn’t sing You Are My Sunshine. You kind of have to judge when to do it and when not to do it. But more or less [the response has] been positive.” Jan Kirk, one of the attendees at the morning tea, is full of praise for Hurley’s song choices. “I loved all of them, I was brought up on these songs,” she says, singling out You Are My Sunshine because she used to sing it “jokingly” with her husband. Peter MacLeod-Miller, archdeacon at St Matthew’s Anglican Church in Albury, describes Hurley as “amazing” and a “secret weapon”, while the singing sessions are “like therapy”. He insists it is not just the war widows who respond – he’s seen the singing go down just as well with children, mental health professionals and Indigenous Australians. MacLeod-Miller and a Government House minder both cite a trip to Weipa in the Pilbara – even miners are not immune to the charms of group singing. “She got a group of miners in northern Australia to sing You Are My Sunshine three times … a stick of gelignite couldn’t do that, to move a group of miners,” MacLeod-Miller says. “It’s an amazingly democratic thing to do. It’s counter-cultural … it’s almost subversive – if you don’t think the office [of governor general] belongs in the museum, well, she turns it into a gymnasium, stretching people in new ways.” Jim Smail, a Canberra Legacy member who knows Linda from the St Andrews Presbyterian church and its choir, says he was honoured that Linda came from Sydney back to Canberra to sing at his wife’s funeral three years ago. Smail has been to the widows’ morning tea before but “this is the first time since I’ve been involved in it that we’ve had a sing-song”. “But then, of course, the terrier behind this is Linda … [It’s usually] just a couple of speeches and the ladies enjoy talking to each other. “Oh yes absolutely [I prefer it this way],” he says, with extra praise for Linda’s “beautiful” composition. Hurley is also a patron of Solid Rock, a Christian ministry to women in defence, is known to hula hoop to keep fit and lists among other interests recycling and reducing the use of plastics. “I am a grassroots environmental person – I can’t control global warming but I can actually control what comes into my house and what I buy,” she says. “There are so many things in packaging that we shouldn’t have,” she says, citing plastic in sticks of cotton-tipped buds, hooks on products like socks and wrapped fruit. “I don’t know what I can do – I’m still thinking about that,” she says, suggesting anti-waste and recycling forums at Government House as a possibility. Next week Hurley will also meet with the Australian Packaging Covenant Organisation, a not-for-profit that aims to reduce harmful packaging. But in the meantime she’s happy to be known for the singing. “I think … as the wife of a governor or governor general, you need to have ownership of something,” she says. “No matter who your partner – whether it’s a male or a female in the big position – we’re always a team. I would say that most husbands and wives … do it as a team. “I can have my thing and David has his thing. He’s the governor general, there’s no way in this planet I want to be a governor general but I love being part of the team doing the things that I can do to help people.”
